ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Does your child like to play with other children?
Notes: 1 = Very much so; 2 = Moderately so; 3 = Moderately little; 4 = Very little

ElementDescription: How motivated is your child to be with other children?
Notes: 1 = Extremely motivated; 2 = Somewhat motivated; 3 = Very little motivated; 4 = Not at all motivated

ElementDescription: How challenging is it for your child to make friends with other children?
Notes: 1 = Extremely challenging; 2 = Somewhat challenging; 3 = Very little challenging; 4 = Not at all challenging

ElementDescription: How challenging is it for your child to maintain friendships with other children?
Notes: 1 = Extremely challenging; 2 = Somewhat challenging; 3 = Very little challenging; 4 = Not at all challenging

ElementDescription: If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They are not that interested in making friends
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They are really interested in making friends, but seem to not know how to do it
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They doesn't initiate conversation
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They becomes too excited around other kids and have difficulty calming down
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They avoid other kids
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They express a lot of negative emotion (e.g. sadness, anger, frustration, fear)
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): Other kids think that they like to be "in charge" too often
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): Other kids think that they do not cooperate or share
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): They don't acknowledge other children
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): Other
Child struggles with friendships because: Other (describe)
If you think that your child struggles with friendships, what are the reasons? (circle all that apply): My child does not struggle with friendships.
Does your child express empathy towards other children's suffering (i.e.do they feel very bad if a child is getting teased or has gotten hurt)?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, somewhat; 3 = No

ElementDescription: Does your child comfort children who are suffering?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, somewhat; 3 = No

ElementDescription: Does your child fight (verbally or physically) with other children?
If your child does fight (verbally or physically) with other children, how often?
Notes: 0 = Answered "No" to 8a; 1 = Very often (daily or weekly); 2 = Occasionally (monthly); 3 = Almost never (once or twice a year)

ElementDescription: Does your child tease other children?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, occasionally; 3 = No

ElementDescription: Do other children tease your child?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, occasionally; 3 = No

ElementDescription: Does your child have a best friend?
Does your child have a small group of friends?
Would you describe your child as well-liked by other children?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, somewhat; 3 = No

ElementDescription: Would you describe your child as a popular child in school?
Notes: 1 = Yes, very much; 2 = Yes, somewhat; 3 = No

ElementDescription: What do you think other children like most about your child?
What do you think other children like least about your child?
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): School
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): Lives in neighborhood or same building
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): Organized family activity (e.g. church, temple)
Organized family activity: (transcribe)
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): Organized extracurricular activity (e.g. dance class, scouts)
Organized extracurricular activity: (transcribe)
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): Child of a family friend
How does your child know his/her closest friend (circle one): Other
Closest friend Other: (transcribe)
